titleStmt.title: A chaotic digital secure communication based on a modified gravitational search algorithm filter

affiliation.orgName: College of Computer Science and Technology & College of Software
College of Computer Science and Technology & College of Software

analytic.title: A chaotic digital secure communication based on a modified gravitational search algorithm filter

biblStruct.note: Received 8 April 2011 Received in revised form 18 April 2012 Accepted 20 April 2012

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Secure communication Message estimation Gravitational search algorithm Chaos

div.p: Research in recent years has seen the development of chaotic systems for secure communication. However, most chaotic systems fail to compensate for channel noise which often degrades the performance of chaos-based secure communication systems. In this work, we propose a chaotic secure communication scheme based on the Modified Gravitational Search Algorithm (MGSA), which minimizes premature convergence of Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA). Here, we apply the MGSA-based filter to the proposed communication scheme to reduce channel noise. Computer simulations with the unified chaotic map are done to verify the feasibility of the proposed secure communication scheme. The results show that the proposed new scheme accurately estimates the states and information symbols, and provides a lower bit error rate (BER) than existing secure communication schemes. Furthermore, the MGSA is tested on the nonlinear filter modeling and compared with GSA and particle swarm optimization (PSO). The results confirm the high performance of the MGSA-based filter in parameters estimation of nonlinear filter modeling. In other words, the more accurately the MGSA estimates the parameters, the more noise the filter reduces.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Chaos has been extensively applied in many highly complex nonlinear systems. The use of chaotic systems for secure communication has been widely studied due to its interesting intrinsic features such as ergodicity, sensitivity to initial conditions and system parameters [4,8,11,13,18,19,37]. Since Pecora and Carroll presented the concept of chaotic synchronization for two identical chaotic systems in 1990 [29], there have been tremendous efforts to construct chaotic secure communication systems [3,15,22,[25][26][27]39,40,45,49]. Hua et al. proposed a secure communication scheme in which useful information is embodied in the parameter of chaotic systems and a unified chaotic system is used to encrypt the emitted signal [15]. Chang [3] suggested a system for digital signal transmissions which made use of the chaotic map's parameter to accomplish its encryption process. The authors in [22] studied the design and implementation of digital secure communication systems via synchronized chaotic circuits. Other chaotic techniques, such as chaotic masking [3,25], chaotic switching [45] and chaos shift keying (CSK) [11,26,39], have been employed to tackle the problems of chaotic secure communication, and differential chaos shift keying (DCSK) [8] and chaotic frequency modulation [40] are also utilized in chaotic systems.

Nevertheless, most systems do not take into account channel noise, which is ubiquitous in the public channel during transmission and often degrades the performance of chaos-based secure communication systems [21]. Hence, it is important to remove noise before a signal is processed. For this purpose, many denoising techniques, such as particle filtering or extended fractional Kalman filtering techniques, have been suggested in chaotic secure communication [18,27,37,49].

Nonlinear filters are often used to eliminate noise in secure communication systems. Despite their effectiveness in removing noise, these techniques tend to destroy features of the signals. To improve the performance of digital filters, many adaptive digital filters have been proposed in the recent years and widely applied to many fields including communication systems, image processing, system identification, and signal processing [9,33,36]. The aim of the adaptation is to adjust the coefficients of digital filters to estimate the parameters of an actual unknown system. Typically, gradient-based iterative search algorithms are used for minimization of an objective function (generally the mean square error between desired signal and estimated filter output). However, when the objective function is non-smooth, gradient-based methods often cannot converge towards the global minimum making them unsuitable for practical applications. Heuristic optimization methods, in which the gradient is not required, have been found to achieve a global optimal solution and offer remarkable advantages in solving complex optimization problems. Many well-known heuristic optimization methods, such as genetic algorithms (GA) [2,14,38,43,48], colony optimization (ACO) [5,6,10,16,32], and particle swarm optimization (PSO) [17,20,34,35,42] are widely employed in filtering problems and system identification [1,7,41].

Gravitational search algorithm (GSA) is one of the newest heuristic algorithms inspired by the law of gravity and mass interactions [31]. In GSA, every particle attracts every other particle with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. Gravity is a force which pulls all objects together. As this force absorbs every other particle, there will not be any recovery for the algorithm if premature convergence happens. In other words, after becoming converged, the algorithm loses its ability to explore and then becomes inactive. Therefore, new operators should be added to GSA in order to increase its flexibility. In light of these conditions, we propose a modified gravitational search algorithm (MGSA) by introducing a new chaotic operator to overcome premature convergence.

Nonlinear rational filter estimation using GSA has been introduced in Rashedi et al. [30]. But the GSA-based filter modeling has not yet been applied to the problem of chaotic secure communication in the context of noise. In the present work, we propose a new chaotic secure communication based on a nonlinear rational filter, where a MGSA is used to achieve a global optimal solution. Different sets of initial population are tested to verify the performance of the MGSA-based filter modeling, and the results are compared with similar runs using GSA and PSO.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we provide a brief summary of GSA. Section 3 explains the MGSA. Section 4 introduces a nonlinear filter modeling which estimates messages online. In Section 5 we present the proposed chaotic secure communication scheme. The results of the work are presented and discussed in Section 6. Finally, we provide conclusions in Section 7.

div.head: Gravitational search algorithm (GSA)
div.p: In this section we provide summary of GSA. GSA is a newly developed stochastic search algorithm based on the law of gravity and mass interactions [12,31]. This approach provides an iterative method that simulates mass interactions, and moves through a multi-dimensional search space under the influence of gravitation. In GSA, agents are considered as objects and their performances are measured by their masses; these objects attract each other by gravitational force which causes a global movement of all objects towards objects with heavier masses [31].
Assumed there are k objects (masses), the position of the ith object is defined as Eq. ( 1):
div.formula: X i ¼ x 1 i ; . . . ; x d i ; . . . ; x n i À Á ; i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; k;ð1Þ
div.p: where x d i denotes the position of ith object in the dth direction. The force exerting on the object i from the object j is defined as Eq. ( 2):
div.formula: F d ij ðtÞ ¼ G M i ðtÞ Â M j ðtÞ R ij ðtÞ þ e x d j ðtÞ À x d i ðtÞ ;ð2Þ
div.p: where M j is the mass related to object j, M i is the mass related to object i, G is gravitational constant at time t, e is a small constant, and R ij (t) is the Euclidian distance between two objects i and j. The total force F d i (t) that exerts on object i in the dth direction is a randomly weighted sum of dth components of the forces from other agents:
div.formula: F d i ðtÞ ¼ X k j¼1;j-i rand j F d ij ðtÞ;ð3Þ
div.p: where rand j is a uniform random variable in the interval [0, 1]. The acceleration of the object i; a d i (t), at time t and in the dth direction, is given as Eq. ( 4):
div.formula: a d i ðtÞ ¼ F d i ðtÞ M ii ðtÞ ;ð4Þ
div.p: where M ii is the inertial mass of the object i. Its next velocity v d i ðt þ 1Þ and its next position x d i (t + 1) are calculated as Eqs. ( 5) and ( 6):
div.formula: v d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ rand i Â v d i ðtÞ þ a d i ðtÞ;ð5Þ
x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ;ð6Þ
div.p: where rand i is a uniform random variable in the interval [0, 1]. This random number is applied to give a randomized characteristic to the search, v d i (t) and x d i (t) are its current velocity and position, respectively. The masses of objects are evaluated by the fitness function. Assuming the equality of the gravitational and inertia mass, the mass M i (t) is updated by Eqs. ( 8)- (11): where fit i (t) represents the fitness value of the object i at time t. A larger mass indicates a more efficient object. This means that more efficient objects possess greater attractions and move more slowly. In this work, the fitness function is given as Eqs. ( 12) and ( 13):
div.formula: M i ¼ M ii ; i ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; k;ð7Þ
m iðtÞ
fitðtÞ ¼ À minðMSEÞ;ð12Þ
MSE ¼ 1 L X L t¼1 ðxðtÞ À xðtÞÞ 2 ;ð13Þ
div.p: where xðtÞ is the estimated signal, x(t) is the actual noisy signal, and L is the length of the input signal. The flow chart of GSA is shown by Fig. 1 3. The modified gravitational search algorithm (MGSA)
In this section, we introduce a chaotic operator as a modification to the GSA.

In the updating stage of objects' position in the original GSA, a random number is used to overcome premature convergence and to avoid local minima. To enhance the ability of escaping from premature convergence and local minima, a chaotic operator is inserted into the standard GSA based on chaotic dynamic.

div.head: Fitness evaluation of objects
div.p: Updating best(t), worst(t) and M i (t) for i = 1, 2,. . . Chaos is a kind of nonlinear dynamic that can be used for global optimization due to its ergodicity and random nature. Searching with chaotic variables is often superior to random search [24,28,44,46,47]. Therefore, we add a chaotic operator to the original search algorithm. The chaotic operator is implemented as follows:
Step 1: Generate a d-dimensional random vector c d 1 2 ½0; 1, and then produce new chaotic vectors with iteration
div.formula: c d i ¼ 4 c d iÀ1 ð1 À c d iÀ1 Þ, i = 2, . . . , k,
div.p: where k represents the size of objects (masses).
Step 2: Add all the chaotic vectors to search space. The velocity updating equation in original GSA is modified as Eq. ( 14):
div.formula: v d i ðt þ 1Þ 0 ¼ rand i Â v d i ðtÞ þ n c d i À 0:5 À Á Â Ã þ a d i ðtÞ; i ¼ 1; . . . ; k;ð14Þ
div.p: where c i is a chaotic vector, n is a factor to control the chaos scope, rand i is a uniform random variable in the interval [0, 1]. The Logistic map is used to generate chaotic variables.
Step 3: Calculate the position updating equation using the modified velocity updating equation as Eq. ( 15):
div.formula: x d i ðt þ 1Þ 0 ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ 0ð15Þ
div.p: The flow chart of the MGSA equipped with the chaotic operator is shown in Fig. 2.

div.head: Nonlinear filter modeling
div.p: In this section, nonlinear filter modeling is described. Linear filters are very often ineffective when signals possess certain features such as impulse-like behavior, non-stationarity, and non-symmetry [23]. To overcome this constraint, nonlinear rational filters have been extensively applied in some areas due to their robustness in signal-preserving capability [23].

The nonlinear rational filter model is defined by the ratio of two polynomial filter expressions. The general difference equation of the dynamic nonlinear rational filter can be obtained as Eq. ( 16) [23]:
div.formula: yðtÞ ¼ aðtÞ bðtÞ þ xðtÞ ¼ a½xðt À 1Þ; . . . ; xðt À N x Þ; yðt À 1Þ; . . . ; yðt À N y Þ b½xðt À 1Þ; . . . ; xðt À M x Þ; yðt À 1Þ; . . . ; yðt À M y Þ þ xðtÞ;ð16Þ
div.p: where x(t) and y(t) are the input and output signal of the rational nonlinear filter at time t, respectively, x (t) is a uniformly distributed random noise, M x and M y represent the number of previous inputs and outputs required in the denominator, respectively, and N x and N y denote the number of previous inputs and outputs required in the numerator polynomial, respectively. In general, a(t) and b(t) are the function of previous inputs and outputs. They can be expressed as Eqs. ( 17) and ( 18) [23]: where âðtÞ and bðtÞ are the numerator and denominator polynomials, respectively, ŷðtÞ denotes the output of signals estimated at time t, and ĥdi ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; denÞ and ĥni ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; numÞ are the estimated parameters of the nonlinear rational filter found by the MGSA.

div.head: The proposed secure communication scheme based on the MGSA filter modeling
div.p: In this section, we provide detailed descriptions of the proposed secure communication scheme utilizing the MGSA-based filter modeling.

div.head: The unified chaotic system
div.p: The unified chaotic system is a generalized system representing Lorenz, Lü and Chen chaotic systems, and is described by System (22):
div.formula: _ x 1 ¼ ð25a þ 10Þðx 2 À x 1 Þ _ x 2 ¼ ð28 À 35aÞx 1 À x 1 x 3 þ ð29a À 1Þx 2 _ x 3 ¼ À aþ8 3 x 3 þ x 1 x 2 8 > < > : :ð22Þ
div.p: Obviously, System ( 22) is a Lorenz system for a = 0, and for a = 1 it denotes a Chen system. When a = 0.8, System ( 22) is a critical system. Actually, System ( 22) is always chaotic for the whole interval a 2 [0, 1]. In our secure communication system, the above unified chaotic system is considered as both a transmitter and a receiver to send and recover useful messages secretly. Parameter a of ( 22) plays an important role because the useful message is encrypted through a.
Consider a demodulation procedure as System (23) [14]:
div.formula: _ h ¼ Àu x 1 x 2 x 3 þ u b; b ¼ À 1 2 u ln x 2 3 À h; â ¼ 3 b À 8;ð23Þ
div.p: where â is the estimate of a and u denotes a positive constant.

Theorem 1 [14]. Parameter a can be recovered if the time derivative of a is less than a positive constant C in the unified chaotic system. The error system of System (22) and System (23) can be defined as System (24):
div.formula: jeðtÞj 6 C u þ eð0Þ À C u expðÀutÞ ;ð24Þ
div.p: where eðtÞ ¼ a À â, u is a positive constant.

div.head: Secure communication scheme description based on the MGSA-based filter modeling
div.p: This sub-section provides a description of our secure communication scheme which can be seen in Fig. 3. In this scheme, information signals are encrypted by an encryption rule. Then, a technique based on chaotic modulation is used to send the encrypted signals through the public channel. At the receiver's end, the estimates of states and parameter are achieved and recovered. The estimate of information signals is then retrieved by a decryption rule in the receiver. It is impossible for an intruder to recover the masked states because the chaotic unified system and its varying parameter are completely unknown. In sum, the communication scheme consists of encoding, the MGSA-based filtering, a chaotic receiver, and a decoder.

div.head: Encoding
div.p: In the encoding step, the data signal s(t) 2 {0, 1} is encoded as a continuous-time carrier signal with N periods through the parameter a(t) in an unified chaotic system. Consider the following encoding procedure for a (t) 2 [0, 1]:
div.formula: aðtÞ ¼ 1 À cos 2 2p T t; if sðtÞ ¼ 0; 1 À sin 2 2p T t; if sðtÞ ¼ 1; (ð25Þ
div.p: where T represents a modulation period of carrier signals, and nNT 6 t < (n + 1)NT, for n = 0, 1, 2, . . .

div.head: MGSA-based filtering
div.p: Because of the existence of noise x(t), the chaotic states x 1 (t), x 2 (t), and x 3 (t) recovered in the received become x 1 (t) + x 1 (t), x 2 (t) + x 2 (t), and x 3 (t) + x 3 (t). To reduce the noise, we use the MGSA-based filter modeling proposed above to estimate x 1 (t), x 2 (t), and x 3 (t). And x1 ðtÞ, x2 ðtÞ, and x3 ðtÞ are the outputs of the MGSA-based filter modeling.

div.head: Chaotic receiver
div.p: System (23) is the demodulation procedure to retrieve a(t). However, due to the channel noise x(t), the chaotic states recovered in the receiver are x1 ðtÞ; x2 ðtÞ, and x3 ðtÞ, not x 1 (t), x 2 (t), and x 3 (t). Consequently, the demodulation procedure is altered as System (26):
div.formula: _ h ¼ Àu x1 x2 x3 þ u b; b ¼ À 1 2 u ln x2 3 À h; â ¼ 3 b À 8;ð26Þ
div.p: where x1 ðtÞ; x2 ðtÞ, and x3 ðtÞ are the outputs of the MGSA-based filter modeling.

div.head: Decoding
div.p: We design a decoding scheme to estimate the useful message after achieving âðtÞ through the above demodulation procedure. Consider gðtÞ
div.formula: ¼ 1 À sin 2 2p
div.p: T t as a reference signal according to Eq. (25). If the difference between g(t) and âðtÞ is equal to zero, this indicates that the recovered byte is 1. Conversely, if the difference is equal to cos 4p T t, it means the recovered code is 0. Thus, the decoding method is carried out as in System (27):
div.formula: ŝðtÞ ¼ 1; if R ðnþ1ÞNT nNT jgðtÞ À âðtÞjdt 6 NT=p; 0; if R ðnþ1ÞNT nNT jgðtÞ À âðtÞjdt > NT=p; (ð27Þ

div.head: Experiment results
div.p: In this section, we conduct several tests to validate the performance of our proposed scheme. We also compute the BER for our scheme and other schemes [4,22] in the context of noise. The MGSA, together with GSA and PSO, is employed in parameter estimation experiments and the procedure is validated by comparing experimental and simulated results.

div.head: Experiment results of chaotic secure communication scheme
div.p: We employ a series of digital sequences s(t) = {010000011111011010. . .} to verify the performance of the proposed communication system. All procedures are implemented in the MATLAB programming language with the sampling period Fig. 4 displays the chaotic signal x 1 (t), x 2 (t), and x 3 (t) without channel noise. We can see that chaotic dynamics are preserved completely. Fig. 5 shows the comparison results between a(t) and âðtÞ from t = 0 to 100 and from t = 100 to 200. From Fig. 5 we can see that both signals are almost identical. We obtain ŝðtÞ ¼ f010000011111011010 . . .g through System (27), which is almost equal to s(t). This indicates the feasibility of the proposed communication scheme.

To demonstrate the performance of the system in the context of channel noise, the noise is added to the three chaotic state signals, and the signal to noise ratios (SNR) are set to SNR(x 1 ) = 20log 10 {j}x 1 /x 1 j, SNR(x 2 ) = 20log 10 jx 2 /x 2 j, SNR(x 3 ) = 20log 10 jx 3 /x 3 j. A comparison between a(t) and âðtÞ with N = 2 can be seen in Fig. 6. From the computer simulation results, we can see that the demodulated message is slightly distorted because of noise; however, by performing the MGSAbased filter modeling, the original signal is essentially recovered. Additional simulation results considering different N and x are listed in Tables 123.

We also compute the BER for our scheme and other schemes [4,22] in the context of noise. The results are shown in Fig. 7. Here, it is clearly seen that the performance of the proposed scheme is superior to that of other schemes, and test results achieve a significantly lower BER. x i (t) 2 [À0.03, 0.03], for i = 1, 2, 3.

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Evaluation of BER under N = 1 and different channel noises.

div.head: Mean of SNR (x 1 )(dB)
div.p: Mean of SNR (x 2 )(dB) Mean of SNR (x 3 )(dB) BER (%) We compute x d i and v d i according to Eqs. ( 28) and ( 29) in PSO:
div.formula: x d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ x d i ðtÞ þ v d i ðt þ 1Þ;ð28Þ
v d i ðt þ 1Þ ¼ wðtÞv d i ðtÞ þ c 1 r 1i pbest d i À x d i ðtÞ þ c 2 r 2i gbest d À x d i ðtÞ ;ð29Þ
div.p: where r 1i and r 2i represent two uniform random variables in the range [0, 1], c 1 = c 2 = 2, and the inertia weight w declines linearly from 0.9 to 0.2. Also,
div.formula: X i ¼ x 1 i ; x 2 i ; . . . ; x n i À Á and V i ¼ v 1 i ; v 2 i ; . . . ; v n i À Á represent
0:3y 2 ðt À 1Þ þ 0:8xðt À 1Þ þ 0:6yðt À 2Þ 1 þ x 2 ðt À 1Þ þ y 2 ðt À 1Þ þ xðtÞ;ð30Þ
yðtÞ ¼ h n1 y 2 ðt À 1Þ þ h n2 xðt À 1Þ þ h n3 yðt À 2Þ 1 þ h d1 x 2 ðt À 1Þ þ h d2 y 2 ðt À 1Þ :ð31Þ
div.p: A simulation with noise x(t) 7, we can see that the means of parameters estimated using GSA is better than those using PSO, while the means using the MGSA are the best among the three algorithms. The means of MSE using PSO, GSA and the MGSA are 3.385 Â 10 À5 , 4.331 Â 10 À6 , and 4.300 Â 10 À6 respectively, and the mean of MSE using the MGSA is the minimal among the three algorithms. Therefore, compared with the two other methods, the MGSA-based filter outperformed the others.

In order to explain further the efficiency of the MGSA-based filter, we use different algorithms in the same filter modeling to estimate x 1 (t) and s(t). Fig. 8a-c, respectively, show the comparisons of the true and estimated x 1 (t) from t = 0 to 50 using PSO, GSA and the MGSA. According to Fig. 8, we can see that GSA have less deviations than PSO between the true and estimated states, while with the MGSA the true and estimated states are almost identical. Fig. 9a-c, respectively, show the comparisons of the true and estimated s(t) from t = 0 to 50 by using PSO, GSA and the MGSA. According to Fig. 9, it can be seen that GSA has less deviations than PSO between the true and estimated signals, while with the MGSA the true and estimated scheme consisting of an encoder, a chaotic transmitter, chaotic filtering, a chaotic receiver, and a decoder. Comparisons with GSA and PSO show the MGSA is more precise than GSA itself when applied to the parameters estimation of the nonlinear filter modeling. Simulations with unified chaotic maps verify the feasibility and the superiority of the proposed secure communication scheme.

To maintain stability, the search space is confined in the range [0, 4].In our simulation, we compare the MGSA-based filter with a GSA-based filter and a PSO-based filter. Here we only give the experimental results for noise x(t) 2 [À0.03, 0.03]. Thirty optimization runs with different random sets of initial population for modeling the nonlinear rational filter are made, and the comparison results are presented in Tables4-6. Tables 4-6 lists filter parameters estimated by the MGSA, GSA, and PSO when x(t) 2 [À0.03, 0.03], where h n1 , h n2 , h n3 , h d1 , h d2 represent the estimated parameters, and MSE represents the mean square error of the input signal and output signal in filter modeling. Table 7 lists the mean of filter parameter estimated by the MGSA, GSA, and PSO with x(t) 2 [À0.03, 0.03] and mean of MSE. According to Table

figure.figDesc: The mean of filter parameter estimated by the MGSA, GSA, and PSO with x(t) 2 [À0.03, 0.03]. are almost identical. From these figures, we can see that the MGSA-based filter modeling can dynamically estimate not only the states but also the binary code message with high accuracy.
